Posts.Content: Sep 2, 2011 06:43AM Delilahbear wrote: Cheryl, I can also relate to your pain. I had BMX in Aug. 2009 and after Oct 09 exchange, followed by Dec 09 exchange to larger implants, I was miserable on the right side. Thought the implants were sitting on rib cage. Everytime I used my right arm, the implant rubbed on rib and I ended up with costochondritis (inflammation of rib and cartlidge). Had 1 cortisone shot which alleviated it for a bit and finally PS decided that the muscles had torn from the pec and serratus muscles where they had been sutured together to make pocket. PS rebuilt pocket with alloderm and made alloderm sling. What a difference! Have had adhesion issues on that side and an implant leak requiring exchange and still some discomfort, but at least it is not rib pain. The left side also had to be rebuilt with alloderm about  months later, but it never has given me any discomfort. Dealing with some axillary node discomfort now, but nothing like the rib pain. I wear a bra 24/7 for comfort. Hope you get some relief soon.
Posts.Title: Could this be scar tissue.?.? bigdogmom2 Delilahbear

Posts.Content: Sep 3, 2011 04:57AM Delilahbear wrote: Cheryl, Yes, my PS went back in through original incisions. My incisions are in IMF although they are a bit higher than the IMF due to size of implants. At least I can wear underwire bras and the wires don't rub on scar areas. Have had original incisions opened up 3 times on left and 4 on right since BMX. They have healed well and don't bother me. One small vertical scar on right side does bother me as it has widened and is very thin. Feels like it folds over on itself. Will have it fixed in November. Armpit lymph nodes we are watching. Another US in Oct. and will see BS next week for routine breast check. She is also my GP so is always watching. PS is in same practice so it is convenient. Hope your pain gets better.
Posts.Title: Could this be scar tissue.?.? bigdogmom2 Delilahbear

Posts.Content: Jun 22, 2012 04:13PM Delilahbear wrote: I had dogears and fatty areas under my arms post BMX. My PS did an in office procedure and cut an shallow oval piece out of each side, including the old scar and resutured them. It made a big difference. First of all he was just going to lipo the areas then decided that to correct it with incisions would take care of dog ears and fatty areas. There was also 2 lipomas in one area. When all was said and done, I am very pleased and went down a bra band size.
Posts.Title: "Dog ears" or "wings" post bilat mastectomy dustycat Cal1960

Posts.Content: Jun 14, 2011 04:27PM Delilahbear wrote: didigro - so sorry about all you have had to go through. I barely tolerate the Vanco when I need it as it eats away the veins so I really cannot imagine the discomfort with a PICC line. anyway, I am responding to saline implant questions. My PS will not use silicone so I only have experienced saline. I have the largest they make and have no ripples or bubbles (they do burp and slosh a bit for about a week after being put in, but then they are silent). They really are pretty soft and always warm. I sleep on my stomach most of the time and they are not a problem. Had one leak after a fall, but that was exchanged in PS office. I hope you can find a solution and an end to your troublesome situation. Hugs. - Delilahbear
Posts.Title: tired of fighting didigro sanbar8771

Posts.Content: Aug 12, 2011 04:03PM Delilahbear wrote: Slinky, How awful and what an elitist attitude the original surgeon has. I work in a transfusion service at our local hospital and know how a situation such as yours can go from being a trickle of blood to a "gusher" in the matter of seconds and we are the responeders to the ER for emergency blood and blood products. I am so glad you were able to get the help you needed from the ER. It is frightening to be away from home and in unfamiliar territory to deal with this, but am glad you had some family for support. I had a similar sort of incident when my donor site from areola construction surgery opened up while I was at work. Left a trail of blood from the bathroom to the ER. At least the ER doc got me patched up and  called my surgeon who met me at his office on Christmas Eve and stitched me up with only my DH and no nurse to assist. I was scared and it was nothing compared to your harrowing ordeal. Please rest and take it easy to ensure you fully heal and get your strength back.
Posts.Title: Almost bled to death after a laproscopic hysterectomy! slinky slinky

Posts.Content: Feb 12, 2011 05:04PM Delilahbear wrote: I chose prophy BMX after MRI Class4 suspicious diagnosis - followed by 4 wires placed by US and these were the 3rd time for biopsies bi-lateral. Radiologists said that the ADH and pappilomas were so dense that the biopsies would be never ending. I also had bi-lat pappilomas in ducts so nipples leaked gross greenish stuff and had ductal excision. While the road to reconstruction has not been an easy one, I would make the same decision again. So far insurance has been paying, slowly after endless medical reviews, but minimal out of pocket.
Posts.Title: Who decides whether you qualify for a BMX? pejkug3 littleamazon

Posts.Content: Feb 14, 2011 02:17PM Delilahbear wrote: Pejkug3 - I am a plus sized woman who had reconstruction. I was 40D prior to BMX and now am a 40C or D depending on bra style, so recon is not just for thin women. My PS does not want me to lose to much weight or the pockets will get too loose. First time I have ever been told not to lose weight (LOL)! Oh yeah will add that I have saline moderate profile plus smooth rounds by Mentor. Delilahbear
Posts.Title: Who decides whether you qualify for a BMX? pejkug3 littleamazon

Posts.Content: Oct 4, 2011 02:30AM Delilahbear wrote: This is such a personal decision for everyone. I had prophy BMX due to severe papillomatosis with atypical ductal hyperplasia and other stuff. I had 3 biopsies, including ductal excision for papillomas on left breast and ductal excision and wire guided biopsies (3) on right breast. One of the surgeries was only the right breast and one bx on left at same time. After all thiis, abnormal mammo, very abnormal ultrasounds and MRI, I told the BS to take them off. I was through with the leaking nipples from the intraductal papillomas and the other suspicious stuff. Yes, it was radical, but I know without a doubt that I would have had BC within the next year or 2 and am not totally convinced they saw everything on pathology after BMX. Had a chest x-ray and my BS put neoplasm of breast and HX of breast cancer as diagnosis, so I am guessing that she has determined what I suspected all along that there was something there. I am asking her why the diagnosis for chest x-ray, but I feel so much more peace of mind with the BMX. It has not been easy with the reconstructive surgeries, but I feel better for having gone through them rather than the surgeries plus chemo and/or rads. Good luck with whatever decision you make.
Posts.Title: How do you know if Mastectomy is right for me? vanlex the7gerbers

Posts.Content: Aug 2, 2010 06:54PM Delilahbear wrote: catheysue, just reread one of your earlier posts and realized you had surgery last Friday. I hope you are recovering well. My recoveries were unremarkable, except for the adhesive issues. I only took codiene once or twice and then did not need it. Can't take percocet as it is Tylenol based. (also allergic to tylenol which drive the BS and PS crazy to find non-tylenol based pain relievers). Sending warm wishes for a speedy recovery. Also hope pathology comes back B9. Nancy
Posts.Title: Duct Excision Yesterday slyspyder Delilahbear

Posts.Content: Jul 26, 2010 05:35PM Delilahbear wrote: slyspyder - glad your pathology came back B9. I have had ductal excissions for papillomas - once in right breast and once in left. They occurred almost 1 year apart with clear greenish discharge. My right breast was so full of papillomas that they said it would be one biopsy after another and continued ductal excisions on both due to the papillomas. I said enough and also had fibrocystic changes and some ductal hyperplasia. I chose to have bilateral mastectomies rather than deal with the biopsies and further destruction to the breasts. My poor areolas and nipples were becoming a mess. I am happy with my decision although I still have to have some touch-up on the right breast. Good luck in your healing and hope it goes well. Cathysue - hope your path is also B9 and your healing is easy. Nancy
Posts.Title: Duct Excision Yesterday slyspyder Delilahbear

Posts.Content: Aug 2, 2010 06:49PM Delilahbear wrote: catheysue, sorry it has taken me so long to reply. I usually look at the topics on my IPAD and for the life of me, I can't understand why I cannot make a reply to anything using it. Finally turned on the PC and now can respond. After each excission, everything was B9, but with the Bi-Rads being class 4 and suspicious, I was not willing to undergo more biopsies each year. The density and the number of suspicious spots of papillomas made my decision to do the BMX easier. My breast surgeon, who is also my PCP has really supported my decisions and been very vocal that I made the correct decision. I am also becoming very sensitive to any adhesives and some topical antibacterials as well as latex. This means that lessening the exposure through repeated surgeries is a benefit. I also have the peace of mind that my BC risk is now very minimal. I cannot imagine living with the leakage for as long as you did. I had 3 ultrasounds and an MRI which showed the papillomas as suspicious lumps. I did not undergo the ductogram as my BS was confident what was going on. I am also a bit older that you at 58 and did not want to go on with biopsies into retirement and beyond. Hope this helps. Nancy
Posts.Title: Duct Excision Yesterday slyspyder Delilahbear

Posts.Content: Aug 13, 2010 06:49PM Delilahbear wrote: Catheysue, how is your recovery coming along. I haven't heard so am hoping that all is going well. I go in for reconstruction of my reconstruction of the right breast on the 27th. Am hoping that it won't be a difficult recovery as just started a new second job and don't want to take much time off of either it or my primary one. Nancy
Posts.Title: Duct Excision Yesterday slyspyder Delilahbear

Posts.Content: Aug 10, 2011 10:06PM Delilahbear wrote: I am unfamiliar with Flat Epithelial Atypia, but papillomatosis is an all too familiar animal. I had a lumpectomy in 2005 which turned our to be sclerosed papilloma and Atypia with hyperplasia. In 2008 I had a ductal excision due to a intraductal papilloma that caused a constant oozing of the nipple. In 2009 I had the exact same thing on the other breast. Had 2different Ultrasounds which showed multiple papillomas in each breast. Mammo was suspicious and the MRI was BiRads class 4 - suspicious. I had 4 different wire localization biopsies and path came back with papillomas and ductal hyperplasia. Pathologists report strongly suggested papillomatosis as diagnosis and along with the hyperplasia was a higher risk for turning to BC. I said enough with the biopsies as was told they would be never ending with MRI every 6 months and who knows what else. DH and I decided that the answer was to have BMX. While radical and involved more surgeries than I would have thought, I am peace with my decision and happy with the outcome. I was lucky with my PCP being gen. Surgeon who is well known for her breast surgery. Her Ex is plastic surgeon and they operate as a team. Nice to have only one practice to deal with and PS is perfectionist. Hope this long winded saga answers your question or gives you some info.
Posts.Title: Surgery for Flat Epithelial Atypia and Papillomatosis Eluned Eluned

Posts.Content: Mar 27, 2011 09:30PM Delilahbear wrote: From another Nancy - you are not alone. I have been through 4 biopsies, a BMX, two implant exchanges, two rounds of alloderm reconstruction 6 months apart and just last week an implant exchange for a leaking saline implant in the last 1 1/2 years. I just get to the point of having some energy and then wham, another surgery which zapps the old energy. I only had an in office  procedure to exchange the leaking implant last Tuesday and he gave me 50mg benadryl and some versed for sedation. I actually woke up just as he removed the old implant and saw the leak and watched him put in the new one. I am now back to taking 3 hour naps each day after work. Hang in there and listen to your body, if you need to rest do so. My BS says that the body has been through so much that it just takes lots of rest to heal. Delilahbear (Nancy)
Posts.Title: Fatigue after lumpectomy, normal? BioAdoptMom3 Janney03

Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2011 05:16PM Delilahbear wrote: I "hit the wall" so to speak about 3 weeks past BMX. When I went to PS and could not stand for more than a few minutes without extreme fatigue, he told me that the adrenal glands sometimes take a hit. He put me on some steroids for about a week and it really helped. Fast forward about 18 months and a revision, same thing happened. Now on steroids for about a week and feel much better. Don't really like the steroids, but do need to function at work. Just a thought. Delilahbear
Posts.Title: Post-op recovery bi-lat mastectomy SofieKatz Delilahbear

Posts.Content: Jul 8, 2011 08:26PM - edited Jul 8, 2011 08:27PM by Delilahbear I'm so sorry to hear everything you are dealing with. I can't begin to know what it is like to handle the stress of chemotherapy and rads as I had prpophy BMX to avoid those,but I can tell you that the emotional part is a roller coaster, but you want to survive so that's a big step. Don't fret the drains again, while uncomfortable they really should not be that painful, just a nuisance and to me they are a small part of the journey. I actually was relieved to have a drain with my second alloderm repair as had seromas drained several time the first time so drain was easier. I had a hysterectomy 13 years ago and was so relieved to have had that and now have foobs. One of my co-workers tells me, jokingly, that I am not a "real woman" since I have had all the parts removed, but I am a girlie girl and like you overweight. I have found real pleasure in my sexy bras and nighties. My friends think a bad day for me would be not having on a pretty bra ....LOL. My DH is also very supportive and that has been a big help. It is a big plus for you. I wish you a healing journey and am sending hugs your way.
Posts.Title: Emotionally and physically scared of bmx bak94 del4

Posts.Content: Jul 11, 2014 06:55PM Delilahbear wrote: I have been where you are now. The first one on left side, the breast surgeon could feel the mass and did a ductal excision and biopsy. It came back as papilloma and some other stuff. Year later same thing on right side and the papilloma there was hard to find on ultrasound and was found on MRI. Did have ducta excission for that one and 3 other wire guided biopsies, bi-lateral. Due to the diffuse papillomas and atypical metaplastic changes, I went on to have mastectomies. I hope you can get the mass (most likely papilloma) removed and your symptoms resolved. The surgery for the ductal excission was realatively easy and recovery non-eventful. Hope everything is benign and goes well.
Posts.Title: 7 mm mass directly under nipple Pattyshothouse whatnow

Posts.Content: Mar 25, 2011 10:56PM Delilahbear wrote: shannonW - I slept in my recliner for about 2 1/2 weeks post BMX before I could sleep in bed. Would start out in bed and within an hour was back to recliner. This is what my PS told me would happen and that recliner would be best. After my exchange surgeries (X2) and then subsequent revisions with alloderm, I purchased the wedge from Bed, Bath and Beyond and with other pillows have been able to use it, but usually spent at least first night from surgery in recliner. Had an implant replaced (leaking saline) this week and surprisingly it has had absolutely no pain or discomfort, but still set up the wedge and pillows for support or else I would be sleeping on my stomach and burst the incision open. Good luck with your continued recovery.

PS also said that when he does facial surgery he is very careful to make sure he gets it cleaned off as it can cause cataracts. Sorry you also had to have this unpleasant SE of the prep.

Posts.Content: Apr 21, 2011 09:05PM Delilahbear wrote: Soda, My saline implant was only 13 months old when it started leaking. When PS took it out, I came to from the versed anesthesia and saw him squeezing it and the saline bubbling out. Weird, but I was glad it was saline. He replaced it in his office surgical room and I never even had pain from it. Good luck with your replacement.
Posts.Title: Saline implant ruptured Soda Delilahbear

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2010 01:50AM Delilahbear wrote: Leah - I had duct excission on two separate occassions. The first was on the left and I only missed about 2 days of work. A bit painful for a while (ran into everything), but healed well. Almost a year to the day later, I found another duct, this time on the right side that was oozing greenish brown fluid. Had mammo on rt side then US on rt. Both showed dense stuff and so had an MRI followed by bi-lat US. Had extremely dense papillomas throughout both breasts and the MRI was BiRads class 4 - suspicious. Had US wire guided biopsies Bi-lateral X4 with 2 ductal excissions. I later decided that I did not want to go through anything like this again and had Bi-Lateral Mastectomies with reconstruction. Thankfully there was no cancer, but abnormal cell changes so I am glad I made the decision I did. My path reports came back rather quickly and they did do frozen sections of the excisions during surgery. Hope you hear something soon, but from what you wrote about your report, things seem to sound very positive. It is hard waiting. Wishing the best outcome for you Nancy
Posts.Title: Still No Diagnosis. Next, Duct Excision LeahinTexas LeahinTexas

Posts.Content: Feb 24, 2010 06:54PM Delilahbear wrote: Hi JudeMama - I can relate to you on the level of wanting them gone.  I began having biopsy on L breast in Dec. 2005 for a suspicious lump. Had previous needle aspiration of it a year or so earlier. It was sclerotic adenoma and intraductal papillomatosis. Was taken off all estrogen (had hyster/ooph earlier). Each year the mammogram came back as dense tissue but no abnormality. In May 2008 I began oozing greenish yellow fluid from L breast. Ultrasound was not good and they did ductal excission and biopsy - again intraductal papillomas. One year later the oozing began on R breast. This time we had uni-US and it showed very dense areas of papillomas and cysts that the US tech said we could never get it all by biopsy. Next Bi-Lat MRI which came back BiRad class 4 suspicious and bi-lat ultrasound showed dense papillomas. Had one wire guided biopsy on L breast and 3 wire guided biopsies on R as well as 2 ductal excissions on R in July 2009 (all at one time. Radiologist said this was very unusual to have so many wires placed. I LOL that I looked like half of a daddy long legs spider). Prior to having the multiple July biopsies, I told BS to just take them away. She said it was radical and that I needed to think seriously about decision. DH and I went for 2 hour counseling sessions with her to discuss pros and cons and even the pathologist said that given what my history with them was said to consider dense papillomatosis as diagnosis. Long story short, I was afraid that all of the dense stuff was bound to turn into DCIS or worse and not be caught early enough. Was told Mammo every 6 mo and MRI once a year to follow so DH and I agreed that prophy BMX was the way to go. It has not been an easy road, but I know it was the right one. I am happy with my Mentor Mod. Profile Plus 960cc Saline implants and despite 4 surgeries to get here am seeing light at the end of the tunnel. Insurance paid for everything as Medical Necessary until last surgery and am in appeal process due to some re-insurance stuff (my non-profit co. is self-insured) which should be resolved once PS and BS office billing person gets on the ball and sends the records requested. Bottom line is if you want them gone, you should have that option and you will slowly ease the suffering you are currently going through.   Hope this helps. Nany
Posts.Title: I JUST WANT THEM OFF JudeMama Delilahbear

Posts.Content: Jun 4, 2011 08:30PM Delilahbear wrote: Tinkerbell99 - I had pain and much discomfort from my implants rubbing on my ribs, mostly on the right. I Also had smaller implants exchanged for larger to better cover my chest area. My PS tried prednisone injections but that only briefly relieved the inflammation and due to thin skin concerns he didn't want to do it again. He finally decided that the muscle between pec and serratus split and pocket wasn't holding implant. He did a major repair job with alloderm and it is 99% better. I just convince myself that I just have to live with it. It does feel better with a wired bra and I sleep in one every night. Eventually I also had the left side reinforced with alloderm as well. I didn't have drains for either implant exchange and the first alloderm repair did not have a drain, but had to have seroma drained X3. Next alloderm repair I had a drain for a week and it wasn't bad. Hope this answers your questions above. BTW I have saline implants.
Posts.Title: Post Mastectomy Pain Syndrome (PMPS) Deeds Lezza13

Posts.Content: Jun 26, 2010 12:12AM Delilahbear wrote: villagirl - I don't know where you can get bra that zips up front in UK, but Champion makes a sports bra that does and our J.C.Penney dept. store in states carries one. I don't own either, but look on line and you should find something. My mastectomy was bi-lat and PS was such a perfectionist that both boobs are the same and even (though I am worried about what the one with the sling will do on its own when fixed). Yes you will have some extreme pain (that's what meds are for). With the BMX both arms are pretty useless for a few days. No weight on them and every thing hurts like H----! I was told to sleep in recliner and probably did for almost three weeks. I would try bed and get back up and sleep in recliner. DH would then sleep in his so he could be close. For my implant exchange surgeries, I got slanted pillow. It really helps a bunch. I was out of work for 3 weeks and needed every bit of it. I hit the wall at about 2 1/2 weeks and could not even function. PS said adrenal glands took a hit and put me on prednisone. He even asked the nurse if there was a diagnosis code for "Patient looks like S----)? She told him no, but there was one for patient very sick. Best of luck to you in your surgery.  Nancy
Posts.Title: question about after papilloma surgery cupid104 ccongdon

Posts.Content: Jul 11, 2010 05:23PM Delilahbear wrote: Villagirl - So glad you got your date. I know that the waiting is hard. I will be having my right breast implant redo with the alloderm on August 27. I am patiently awaiting this date as it is starting to really bother me. See BS on Wed. for routine 1 year post-op check. I know how you feel with the throat infection. Somehow I managed to come down with a cold for the first time in several years. My husband and I were in Nova Scotia for 2 weeks and probably picked up something there. He had pneumonia earlier this year so his resistance was down and then the cumulative effects of 4 surgeries last year undoubtedly left me a little weak in the immune dept. so we are both suffering. I had to work all weekend and could not call in sick as I have few sick days and need them for surgery. I start a new job on Tuesday so I hope that my cold is better. It is a part time job for some extra income. I had one, but due to staff cutbacks at our local hospital, I was let go. What part of UK are you in? My brother and family lived in Scotland for over 10 years so am familiar with UK. Good Luck with your surgery and I hope that the pain is not too great and that it is successful in aleviating the pain you are currently experiencing. Nancy
Posts.Title: question about after papilloma surgery cupid104 ccongdon

Posts.Content: Jul 19, 2010 09:59PM Delilahbear wrote: villagirl - I am thinking of you and hoping you have good results with your upcoming surgery. Donamaria - Sounds like you have had similar situation to what I had over the past 3 or 4 years I had a greenish watery discharge with my papilloma. Like you the mammogram did not show much but US and MRI did show diffuse papillomatosis. (See my June 24 post above for further details). I do not remember especially painful symptoms post biopsy, but then they did remove my whole duct at the time of biopsy. I also had 3 other sites biopsied at the same time and had them all done under gen. anesthesia. So sorry you are in such pain. I have to say that I am very relieved not to be going through the same thing this year and so glad that my Breast Surgeon was on my side with the BMX. I saw her last week for a year (almost) follow-up and she told me that she had another patient that had papillomatosis. She said she used to see it rarely and no more than once every 18 months and now she has 2 patients with the same diagnosis within a year. She said her other patient does not have it to the extent which I had and only in one breast, not both. BS is very glad we went ahead with the BMX also. It is so nice to have the support of the medical staff when it is prophylactic. At the time she did mine she had a patient who really needed a BMX and did not want to do it and then she had me with the prophy and was ready to put the other mess behind me. She said she really wished I could talk to the other patient, but with our HIPPA privacy laws, that was not an option. Wishing you good news on Friday for your path. report. Nancy
Posts.Title: question about after papilloma surgery cupid104 ccongdon

Posts.Content: Aug 31, 2010 11:26AM Delilahbear wrote: Hi villagirl, Thanks for inquiring after my surgery. The surgery itself went very well- into the OR at 2pm and home by 7:30pm. Monday morning I called PS office to confirm Tues. appt. and said all was well. About 2 hours later something felt off and I noticed that I had a seroma developing. Called PS office back and they fit me in and drained about 90cc off. It seems to be coming back, but I will wait until Fri to see if it gets larger. I have followup appt then. Today I have appt with BS who is also my GP so will see if she thinks it needs following. BS and PS share office and nurse so they can consult if need be. I am off work until next week. So sorry about your experiences and after surgery illnesses. I believe that my immunity has been really compromised. I have been getting colds, etc. that I rarely got before.  This surgery (my5th in a year) has seemed to really been the most difficult to recover from. I have felt yucky and my GI tract is a mess. I cannot believe they found no papillomas. What was the actual path report findings? I hope you can find the cause of your bleeding and no more surgery will be necessary. Take care. Nancy
Posts.Title: question about after papilloma surgery cupid104 ccongdon

Posts.Content: Jun 26, 2012 05:14PM Delilahbear wrote: Vickie, I am so sorry that you have had this hanging over your head for so long. I truly hope everything works out for you this time. I had prophy BMX in 2009 and have had several surgeries but am very pleased with the outcome. I was BMX to TEs and then to implants. Had smallish implants for my frame and hated them and then had them replaced with larger ones and had areola and nipples at the same time. Later I had alloderm placed to repair torn pec muscle and now I am finished (almost 3 years out) and am quite happy and breathe easier without always having another biopsy done. As for the relationship, I can't help much with that. My DH and I discussed everything from the beginning of my decision to have the prophy, went to every doctor appointment with me and was at all of my surgeries waiting to take me home. Guess the best advice I can give is to have open conversation early on and if boyfriend can't handle it you will know early on. It is a difficult time and the surgery can take its toll as well so you need the support and to know you have it before the surgery starts. Good luck with all of your decisions and eventual surgery.
Posts.Title: Prophylactic bilateral mastectomy vickie1 vickie1

Posts.Content: Jun 7, 2012 11:17AM Delilahbear wrote: My BS prescribes Vagifem for me. They discontinued the higher dose and now only have a lower dosage available. It does make a difference. I had prophylactic BMX for ADH and very profuse papillomatosis and BS discontinued my HRT 7 years ago when I first had to have BX for lump that was ADH. Since then I have used Vagifem.
Posts.Title: Vagifem/Estring for high risk people? momoschki momoschki

Posts.Content: Dec 3, 2009 08:36PM Delilahbear wrote: Kimber, I know your delima. I had 6 biopsies and 3 ductal excisions (3 wire guided biopsies and 2 ductal excisions on my right breast and 1 wire guided biopsy on my left all at the same time in July of this year). I had intraductal papillomas that started leaking left last year and right this year. After having the left breast areola cut open 3 times, I said enough is enough and my husband and I discussed PBM and then had two counseling sessions with the surgeon. She agreed with our decision to go ahead with PBM and now 3 months out and getting my implants replaced with larger saline ones in mid Dec. along with the nipple reconstruction, I am glad that I went ahead and had the procedure performed.  It hasn't been the piece of cake my mind told me it would be, but the peace of mind is certainly worth it. I could not endure any more mammos, ultrasounds and MRIs with their uncertainty every few months. My MRI came back bi-rad category 4 suspicious and the pathology was extremely diffuse papillomatosis.This raised my risk as well as being overweight and never having had children. Hope this helps.
Posts.Title: I also need help, advice.... Kimber Lynn3

Posts.Content: Jun 24, 2010 09:55PM Delilahbear wrote: I had a sclerosed papilloma removed 5 years ago and it had some hyperplasia and some other abnormal cells associated with it. It was hard lump and removed through incision around areola. In 2008 I noticed greenish fluid dripping from left breast nipple. It was not pleasant. BS removed the duct and was diagnosed with papillomatosis. Thought all was well until almost exactly 1 year later when the right breast started the same thing. This time I had mammogram, Ultra sound rt side then another bi-lateral ultrasound at a different hospital, followed by MRI. The US techs told me that the papillomas were so dense, especially in the rt. breast that there was no way of removing all of them and the MRI came back Bi-rads Category 4 of 5 suspicious. I had 4 wires inserted (3 on Rt. and 1 on Lft.) using US and mammo, then the excissional  biopsies plus 2 ductal excisions on the rt. Path said diffuse papillomatosis and with this much the chances are much higher of DCIS down the road, especially since I have had so many biopsies and recurrences. My solution - though radical - was a prophylactic BMX last Aug. I have had two different sets of implants and now will have revision on rt. with alloderm sling to correct some thin muscle/skin issues, but would do the whole thing again. It has given me much more peace of mind and my PS did a fantastic job with nipples and aerola grafts.  They really look better than the originals ever did. I am 57 and never had children so that put me at even higher risk, plus some cancer in family and being overweight.
Posts.Title: question about after papilloma surgery cupid104 ccongdon
